○ Sub-Clause 3.3.3.2 The notification shall include a summary of the dissolution process, the final report, and contact details for accessing archived records.

○ Sub-Clause 3.3.3.3 A digital copy of the final notification shall be archived as part of KUCSA’s historical record.

Sub-Section 3.4: Compliance and Legal Safeguards

● Clause 3.4.1 Verification of Legal Compliance:

○ Sub-Clause 3.4.1.1 The Dissolution Committee shall consult with legal advisors to verify that all dissolution activities align with Kenyan law, including the filing of required forms and notifications.

○ Sub-Clause 3.4.1.2 Any unresolved legal issues shall be documented, and the NEC shall maintain a record of attempts made to resolve them in the dissolution report.

● Clause 3.4.2 Liability and Indemnification:

○ Sub-Clause 3.4.2.1 Members of the NEC and Dissolution Committee shall be indemnified for any actions taken in good faith to execute their duties during the dissolution process.

○ Sub-Clause 3.4.2.2 Indemnification shall not apply in cases of proven negligence or misconduct, and legal protections shall be outlined in the final dissolution documentation.

Section 4: Legal and Compliance Obligations

Sub-Section 4.1: Compliance with Kenyan Law

● Clause 4.1.1 Adherence to National and Non-Profit Regulations:

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.1.1 The NEC shall consult with legal counsel to ensure all dissolution activities comply with relevant Kenyan laws, including but not limited to the Non-Governmental Organizations Coordination Act, the Societies Act, and other applicable student association regulations.

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.1.2 Specific attention shall be given to regulatory requirements related to the dissolution of student and non-profit organizations, particularly in terms of asset liquidation, debt settlement, and documentation.

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.1.3 In case of conflicts between KUCSA's internal procedures and Kenyan law, Kenyan law shall take precedence, and the NEC shall make necessary adjustments to the dissolution process.

● Clause 4.1.2 Documentation of All Dissolution Activities:

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.2.1 The NEC shall ensure that all decisions, financial transactions, and distribution of assets are meticulously documented, maintaining transparency and accountability throughout the process.

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.2.2 Copies of all legal documents related to dissolution, including reports, receipts, transfer agreements, and settlement records, shall be retained for a minimum of five years.

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.2.3 The Dissolution Committee shall submit certified copies of the dissolution records to the Registrar of Societies, as well as any other required government body, in accordance with Kenyan law.

● Clause 4.1.3 Public Accessibility and Transparency:

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.3.1 If required by law, the NEC shall make certain dissolution records publicly accessible, including financial statements, the Final Dissolution Report, and a summary of asset distribution.

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.3.2 Requests for public records shall be handled in a timely manner, with the NEC responding to requests within 15 business days.

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.3.3 Any confidential information in these records, such as member lists or private financial details, shall be redacted to ensure compliance with data protection laws.

● Clause 4.1.4 Appointment of a Compliance Officer:

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.4.1 A Compliance Officer shall be appointed by the NEC to oversee adherence to all legal and regulatory standards throughout the dissolution process.

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.4.2 The Compliance Officer shall maintain a checklist of all legal requirements and provide regular updates to the NEC on the status of compliance activities.

○ Sub-Clause 4.1.4.3 The Compliance Officer shall submit a Compliance Report as part of the Final Dissolution Report, certifying that all legal obligations have been met.

Sub-Section 4.2: Right to Appeal

● Clause 4.2.1 Members' Right to Petition the NEC:

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.1.1 Any KUCSA member with standing may submit a written appeal or petition against the dissolution decision within 30 days of the AGM or SGM vote on dissolution.

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.1.2 The petition must clearly outline the grounds for the appeal, such as concerns over procedural fairness, transparency, or financial mismanagement during the dissolution.

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.1.3 The NEC shall acknowledge receipt of the petition within seven days and inform the petitioner(s) of the next steps in the review process.

● Clause 4.2.2 Temporary Suspension of Dissolution Proceedings:

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.2.1 Upon receipt of a valid petition, the NEC shall temporarily halt dissolution proceedings, including the distribution of assets, until the appeal process is complete.

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.2.2 The NEC shall establish an independent review process, appointing a neutral mediator or arbitrator approved by a majority of the NEC members to facilitate the appeal.

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.2.3 The mediator or arbitrator shall have full access to dissolution records and shall conduct a thorough investigation, with a decision reached within 30 days of the appeal submission.

● Clause 4.2.3 Review Outcomes and Actions:

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.3.1 If the appeal is upheld, the NEC shall be required to address any identified issues, including amending procedures, conducting a new dissolution vote, or revising asset distribution plans in compliance with the mediator’s recommendations.

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.3.2 If the appeal is denied, the NEC shall resume the dissolution process, with a final notice issued to all members and stakeholders affirming the decision.

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.3.3 A summary of the mediator’s findings shall be made available to KUCSA members, and a copy shall be included in the Final Dissolution Report for transparency.

● Clause 4.2.4 Appeals Involving Regulatory Authorities:

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.4.1 If the appeal involves significant legal or financial concerns, the NEC may consult with or seek intervention from relevant regulatory authorities, including the Registrar of Societies.

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.4.2 The NEC shall provide a detailed report of the issue to the authority, along with records requested, to assist in the review.

○ Sub-Clause 4.2.4.3 The dissolution process shall not proceed until an official resolution or directive is received from the relevant regulatory authority.

Sub-Section 4.3: Legal Liability and Indemnification

● Clause 4.3.1 Protection of NEC and Dissolution Committee Members:

○ Sub-Clause 4.3.1.1 NEC members and Dissolution Committee members shall be indemnified against personal liability for actions taken in good faith during the dissolution, provided that actions align with KUCSA’s constitutional and legal obligations.

○ Sub-Clause 4.3.1.2 Legal protection shall not apply in cases of proven negligence, fraud, or intentional misconduct, and any member found guilty of such actions shall be subject to legal consequences.

○ Sub-Clause 4.3.1.3 Any legal claims arising from dissolution activities shall be addressed in accordance with Kenyan law, and members may seek legal counsel as needed.

● Clause 4.3.2 NEC’s Responsibility to Mitigate Legal Risks:

○ Sub-Clause 4.3.2.1 The NEC shall take proactive steps to minimize potential legal disputes, including transparent documentation, regular member updates, and adherence to legal guidelines.

○ Sub-Clause 4.3.2.2 The NEC shall purchase liability insurance, if available, to cover potential legal expenses arising from dissolution activities.

○ Sub-Clause 4.3.2.3 In the event of a legal dispute, the NEC shall seek resolution through arbitration or mediation before resorting to court proceedings, where feasible.

Sub-Section 4.4: Compliance with Financial Regulations

● Clause 4.4.1 Financial Audits and Reporting:

○ Sub-Clause 4.4.1.1 The NEC shall conduct a final financial audit within 30 days of the dissolution resolution to ensure that all funds are accurately accounted for and in compliance with financial regulations.

○ Sub-Clause 4.4.1.2 A certified public accountant shall be engaged to review and certify the financial records, ensuring that asset distribution and liability settlement align with legal standards.

○ Sub-Clause 4.4.1.3 A financial compliance report shall be included in the Final Dissolution Report and submitted to regulatory bodies as required.

● Clause 4.4.2 Compliance with Tax Obligations:

○ Sub-Clause 4.4.2.1 All outstanding tax liabilities shall be identified and settled prior to asset distribution to avoid penalties and ensure compliance with Kenya Revenue Authority (KRA) requirements.

○ Sub-Clause 4.4.2.2 The NEC shall file a final tax return with the KRA within 60 days of dissolution and obtain tax clearance to complete the dissolution process.

○ Sub-Clause 4.4.2.3 Documentation of all tax settlements shall be retained as part of the dissolution records and included in the Final Dissolution Report for regulatory review.

CHAPTER 23: MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

Article 59: Administrative Provisions

Section 1: Interpretation

Sub-section 1.1: General Principles

❖ 1.1.1. This Constitution shall be interpreted to promote the objectives, principles, and values of the Kenya Universities and Colleges Students Association (KUCSA).

➢ 1.1.1.1. Objectives shall include the promotion of student welfare, advocacy for academic excellence, and fostering unity among institutions of higher learning.

➢ 1.1.1.2. Principles shall be rooted in fairness, transparency, accountability, and inclusivity.

❖ 1.1.2. Ambiguities shall be resolved in consultation with legal counsel.

➢ 1.1.2.1. The Executive Committee shall initiate consultations with legal experts in cases where ambiguities arise.

➢ 1.1.2.2. Legal interpretations shall prioritize the best interest of KUCSA and its members.

❖ 1.1.3. This Constitution shall align with the national laws of Kenya.

➢ 1.1.3.1. In case of a conflict between this Constitution and national laws, the latter shall prevail.

➢ 1.1.3.2. Provisions of this Constitution shall be reviewed to ensure conformity with any amendments to relevant laws.

Sub-section 1.2: Definitions

❖ 1.2.1. Terms used in this Constitution shall carry their ordinary meaning unless defined within the text.

➢ 1.2.1.1. Where the ordinary meaning is unclear, reference shall be made to authoritative legal and academic sources.

❖ 1.2.2. Specific terms shall be interpreted as per Schedule 1 (Definitions and Terminologies).

➢ 1.2.2.1. The Executive Committee shall update Schedule 1 periodically to reflect emerging terminologies.

➢ 1.2.2.2. Definitions in Schedule 1 shall take precedence over conflicting interpretations in other documents.

❖ 1.2.3. Acronyms and abbreviations used in this Constitution shall be defined in Schedule 1.

➢ 1.2.3.1. Any acronym or abbreviation not defined in Schedule 1 shall be interpreted based on its commonly accepted meaning.

❖ 1.2.4. References to positions, bodies, or documents shall include any future amendments or successors to such entities.

➢ 1.2.4.1. If a referenced entity is dissolved or renamed, the interpretation shall apply to its lawful successor.

Sub-section 1.3: Rules of Interpretation

❖ 1.3.1. The provisions of this Constitution shall be interpreted holistically.

➢ 1.3.1.1. Sections and clauses shall be read in context with the entire document to avoid contradictions.

➢ 1.3.1.2. In cases of conflict between provisions, those promoting the objectives of KUCSA shall prevail.

❖ 1.3.2. Gender neutrality shall be observed in the interpretation of this Constitution.

➢ 1.3.2.1. Words implying one gender shall include all genders unless the context specifies otherwise.

➢ 1.3.2.2. Titles and roles shall be inclusive of all qualified members, regardless of gender.

❖ 1.3.3. Numerical references shall include their plural and singular forms unless explicitly stated otherwise.

Sub-section 1.4: Interpretative Authorities

❖ 1.4.1. The General Assembly shall have the ultimate authority in interpreting this Constitution.

➢ 1.4.1.1. Any member may petition the General Assembly for an interpretation of contentious provisions.

❖ 1.4.2. The Executive Committee may issue interim interpretations for urgent matters.

➢ 1.4.2.1. Such interim interpretations shall be ratified by the General Assembly at the next meeting.

❖ 1.4.3. External arbitration or judicial interpretation may be sought in cases of irreconcilable disputes.

➢ 1.4.3.1. The Executive Committee must approve any external interpretation process by a majority vote.

Sub-section 1.5: Amendments to Interpretation Provisions

❖ 1.5.1. Amendments to this section shall require a two-thirds majority vote at the General Assembly.

➢ 1.5.1.1. Proposals for amendments must be submitted to the Secretary-General at least 30 days before the General Assembly.

❖ 1.5.2. Any amendment to the interpretation provisions shall be documented in Schedule 1 for transparency.

Section 2: Transitional Provisions

Sub-section 2.1: Continuity of Existing Structures

❖ 2.1.1. Actions, rules, or regulations established under previous versions of the Constitution shall remain valid unless inconsistent with this version.

➢ 2.1.1.1. Any inconsistency with the current Constitution shall render the affected provisions null and void.

➢ 2.1.1.2. Any rules rendered invalid shall be reviewed and harmonized with this Constitution within six months of its adoption.

❖ 2.1.2. Current office bearers shall continue to serve until the next election cycle.

➢ 2.1.2.1. Office bearers must align their actions with the provisions of this Constitution during the transitional period.

➢ 2.1.2.2. Should any office bearer resign or vacate their position, replacements shall be appointed following this Constitution.

❖ 2.1.3. Committees, sub-committees, and other organs established under the previous Constitution shall remain functional unless dissolved or reconstituted under this Constitution.

➢ 2.1.3.1. Reconstitution of committees must be conducted within 90 days of this Constitution coming into effect.

➢ 2.1.3.2. Committees shall submit reports on their functions and operations to the Executive Committee during the transition.

Sub-section 2.2: Oversight of Transition

❖ 2.2.1. The Executive Committee shall oversee the transition to this Constitution.

➢ 2.2.1.1. The Executive Committee shall establish a Transitional Task Force to coordinate the implementation of new provisions.

➢ 2.2.1.2. The Transitional Task Force shall comprise representatives from the General Assembly, existing committees, and legal advisors.

❖ 2.2.2. Unresolved transitional issues shall be tabled at the next General Assembly for determination.

➢ 2.2.2.1. A comprehensive report of unresolved issues must be presented by the Secretary-General.

➢ 2.2.2.2. The General Assembly may form an Ad Hoc Committee to address particularly complex transitional issues.

❖ 2.2.3. A transitional roadmap shall be prepared and shared with all members within 30 days of this Constitution's adoption.

➢ 2.2.3.1. The roadmap shall detail timelines, key milestones, and responsible parties for implementing transitional provisions.

➢ 2.2.3.2. Progress on the roadmap shall be reviewed bi-monthly by the Executive Committee.

Sub-section 2.3: Transitional Safeguards

❖ 2.3.1. During the transition period, no actions or decisions shall undermine the objectives or principles of KUCSA.

➢ 2.3.1.1. All decisions made during the transitional period must align with the long-term goals of KUCSA

➢ 2.3.1.2. Transitional actions that cause harm or discord among members shall be reviewed immediately by the Executive Committee.

❖ 2.3.2. Existing contractual agreements, partnerships, and obligations shall remain binding unless they conflict with this Constitution.

➢ 2.3.2.1. The Executive Committee shall review all agreements to ensure compliance with this Constitution.

➢ 2.3.2.2. Any amendments to existing agreements shall require approval by the General Assembly.

❖ 2.3.3. Financial management during the transition shall adhere strictly to existing policies until updated regulations under this Constitution are enacted.

➢ 2.3.3.1. The Treasurer shall submit a transitional financial plan within 60 days of this Constitution's adoption.

➢ 2.3.3.2. Any deviations from the financial plan shall require Executive Committee approval.

Sub-section 2.4: Transitional Dispute Resolution

❖ 2.4.1. Disputes arising from the transition shall be addressed promptly to ensure a smooth process.

➢ 2.4.1.1. Transitional disputes shall be referred to the Dispute Resolution Committee for arbitration.

➢ 2.4.1.2. The Dispute Resolution Committee shall issue binding decisions within 14 days of receiving a dispute.

❖ 2.4.2. Where disputes cannot be resolved internally, external arbitration or mediation may be sought.

➢ 2.4.2.1. External mediation shall require a majority vote by the Executive Committee.

Sub-section 2.5: Ratification of Transitional Provisions

❖ 2.5.1. The transitional provisions shall be ratified as part of the overall adoption of this Constitution.

➢ 2.5.1.1. Any proposed amendments to the transitional provisions during implementation must receive a two-thirds majority in the General Assembly.

❖ 2.5.2. These provisions shall remain in effect until the transition is formally declared complete by the Executive Committee.

Section 3: Schedules

Sub-section 3.1: Role of Schedules

❖ 3.1.1. The schedules attached to this Constitution form an integral part of the document.

➢ 3.1.1.1. Schedules shall be referenced and interpreted in conjunction with the main body of the Constitution.

➢ 3.1.1.2. In case of conflict between a schedule and the Constitution, the provisions of the Constitution shall prevail.

❖ 3.1.2. Schedules shall provide detailed guidance on operational matters, such as bylaws, regulations, and definitions.

➢ 3.1.2.1. Schedules shall cover subject areas requiring extensive elaboration, such as financial regulations, electoral procedures, and member conduct.

➢ 3.1.2.2. Each schedule shall be categorized based on its purpose and scope, including but not limited to:

■ 3.1.2.2.1. Administrative guidelines.

■ 3.1.2.2.2. Procedural frameworks.

■ 3.1.2.2.3. Terminology and definitions.

❖ 3.1.3. Schedules shall be regularly reviewed to ensure alignment with KUCSA's objectives and evolving operational needs.

➢ 3.1.3.1. The Executive Committee shall initiate the review process at least once every two years.

➢ 3.1.3.2. Recommendations from members on schedule improvements shall be submitted through the Secretary-General for consideration.

Sub-section 3.2: Amendment of Schedules

❖ 3.2.1. Amendments to schedules must be approved by a two-thirds majority vote at the General Assembly.

➢ 3.2.1.1. Proposed amendments shall be submitted in writing to the Executive Committee at least 30 days prior to the General Assembly.

➢ 3.2.1.2. The Executive Committee shall review and present the proposals with recommendations during the General Assembly.

❖ 3.2.2. Emergency amendments may be enacted by the Executive Committee under extraordinary circumstances.

➢ 3.2.2.1. Such amendments must be ratified by the General Assembly within three months.

➢ 3.2.2.2. Emergency amendments shall be clearly labeled as provisional until ratification.

❖ 3.2.3. Schedules amended under this subsection must be communicated to all members within 14 days of their approval.

➢ 3.2.3.1. Communication methods shall include email notifications, official websites, and physical copies at member institutions.

➢ 3.2.3.2. A summary of the changes shall accompany the full text of the amended schedule.

Sub-section 3.3: Creation of New Schedules

❖ 3.3.1. New schedules may be proposed to address emerging needs or operational gaps.

➢ 3.3.1.1. Proposals for new schedules must outline the purpose, scope, and expected benefits.

➢ 3.3.1.2. Proposals must undergo initial review by the Legal and Compliance Committee before presentation to the General Assembly.

❖ 3.3.2. The adoption of new schedules requires a two-thirds majority vote by the General Assembly.

➢ 3.3.2.1. Newly adopted schedules shall be numbered sequentially and added to the appendix of the Constitution.

➢ 3.3.2.2. The numbering system shall indicate the year of adoption and the schedule's sequence (e.g., Schedule 2024-1).

Sub-section 3.4: Accessibility of Schedules

❖ 3.4.1. All schedules shall be made accessible to KUCSA members at all times.

➢ 3.4.1.1. The Secretary-General shall ensure schedules are uploaded to the official KUCSA website.

➢ 3.4.1.2. Printed copies of schedules shall be available upon request at KUCSA offices.

❖ 3.4.2. Efforts shall be made to present schedules in a clear, concise, and reader-friendly format.

➢ 3.4.2.1. Plain language shall be used where possible, and technical terms shall include explanatory notes.

➢ 3.4.2.2. Translation into other languages may be considered for inclusivity.

Sub-section 3.5: Enforcement of Schedules

❖ 3.5.1. Compliance with schedules is mandatory for all KUCSA members and stakeholders.

➢ 3.5.1.1. Breaches of schedules shall be treated as breaches of the Constitution and handled under applicable disciplinary procedures.

➢ 3.5.1.2. Ignorance of schedule provisions shall not be considered a valid defense against non-compliance.

❖ 3.5.2. The Disciplinary Committee shall oversee enforcement and address violations related to schedules.

➢ 3.5.2.1. Complaints regarding schedule violations shall be submitted in writing to the Disciplinary Committee.

➢ 3.5.2.2. The committee shall issue decisions within 30 days of receiving a complaint.

Article 60: Legal and Operational Framework

Section 1: Intellectual Property Rights

Sub-section 1.1: Ownership

❖ 1.1.1. Intellectual property created under KUCSA activities shall belong to the Association.

➢ 1.1.1.1. This includes but is not limited to logos, trademarks, research, publications, digital content, and event materials.

➢ 1.1.1.2. Intellectual property created collaboratively with external parties shall be governed by specific agreements detailing ownership percentages.

❖ 1.1.2. Exceptions must be documented in written agreements approved by the Executive Committee.

➢ 1.1.2.1. Agreements shall specify the terms of ownership, usage rights, and duration.

➢ 1.1.2.2. Copies of such agreements shall be maintained in the KUCSA archives for reference and transparency.

❖ 1.1.3. Members or third parties creating intellectual property independently while using KUCSA resources or branding must disclose this to the Executive Committee.

➢ 1.1.3.1. The Executive Committee reserves the right to review and assert partial or full ownership if deemed relevant to KUCSA activities.

➢ 1.1.3.2. Disputes arising from such cases shall be resolved under the Dispute Resolution Mechanism outlined in this Constitution.

Sub-section 1.2: Usage Permissions

❖ 1.2.1. Members may use KUCSA intellectual property only with prior written approval.

➢ 1.2.1.1. Requests for usage must include the intended purpose, duration, and any modifications to the intellectual property.

➢ 1.2.1.2. Usage shall be granted based on alignment with KUCSA's mission, values, and objectives.

❖ 1.2.2. Unauthorized use shall attract penalties as per the bylaws.

➢ 1.2.2.1. Penalties may include fines, suspension of membership rights, or legal action.

➢ 1.2.2.2. Repeat violations shall result in escalated disciplinary measures, including permanent expulsion.

❖ 1.2.3. Use of KUCSA intellectual property by external entities must be formalized through a licensing agreement.

➢ 1.2.3.1. Licensing agreements shall include terms regarding royalties, usage limitations, and intellectual property protection.

➢ 1.2.3.2. Unauthorized reproduction, distribution, or alteration by external entities shall be prosecuted to the full extent of the law.

Sub-section 1.3: Protection and Enforcement

❖ 1.3.1. KUCSA shall actively protect its intellectual property from unauthorized use or infringement.

➢ 1.3.1.1. The Legal and Compliance Committee shall oversee intellectual property registration and protection.

➢ 1.3.1.2. KUCSA shall seek legal remedies, including but not limited to cease-and-desist orders, where infringement occurs.

❖ 1.3.2. Members shall report any suspected misuse or infringement of KUCSA intellectual property to the Secretary-General.

➢ 1.3.2.1. Reports must include detailed descriptions and evidence of the alleged misuse or infringement.

➢ 1.3.2.2. The Executive Committee shall investigate and take appropriate action within 30 days of receiving a report.

Sub-section 1.4: Revenue from Intellectual Property

❖ 1.4.1. KUCSA shall retain all revenue generated from its intellectual property unless otherwise stipulated by agreement.

➢ 1.4.1.1. Revenue streams include licensing fees, royalties, sales, and sponsorships.

➢ 1.4.1.2. Revenue generated from intellectual property shall be used to fund KUCSA activities, projects, and scholarships.

❖ 1.4.2. Members involved in the creation of revenue-generating intellectual property may be eligible for recognition or rewards.

➢ 1.4.2.1. Such rewards shall be determined by the Executive Committee based on the nature and impact of the intellectual property.

➢ 1.4.2.2. Members may appeal decisions regarding recognition or rewards through the Dispute Resolution Mechanism.

Sub-section 1.5: Confidentiality in Intellectual Property

❖ 1.5.1. Members shall maintain confidentiality regarding intellectual property under development.

➢ 1.5.1.1. Disclosure of sensitive intellectual property details without authorization shall be considered a serious breach of conduct.

➢ 1.5.1.2. Confidentiality obligations shall continue even after a member’s association with KUCSA ends.

❖ 1.5.2. KUCSA shall take necessary precautions to protect the confidentiality of its intellectual property.

➢ 1.5.2.1. Measures include secure storage of documents, non-disclosure agreements, and controlled access.

➢ 1.5.2.2. Breaches of confidentiality by any party shall result in immediate legal action.

Section 2: Indemnification and Liability

Sub-section 2.1: Protection of Members

❖ 2.1.1. KUCSA shall indemnify officials and members for actions taken in good faith while performing official duties.

➢ 2.1.1.1. Indemnification shall cover legal costs, settlements, and damages arising from lawsuits or claims.

➢ 2.1.1.2. Members seeking indemnification must promptly notify KUCSA of the claim and cooperate fully in the defense.

➢ 2.1.1.3. The Executive Committee shall assess each case to determine eligibility for indemnification.

❖ 2.1.2. Indemnification does not cover gross negligence or willful misconduct.

➢ 2.1.2.1. Gross negligence includes failure to perform duties with the standard care expected of a reasonable person in similar circumstances.

➢ 2.1.2.2. Willful misconduct refers to intentional or reckless behavior that disregards KUCSA’s principles, policies, or laws.

➢ 2.1.2.3. KUCSA reserves the right to revoke indemnification if evidence of negligence or misconduct emerges during proceedings.

❖ 2.1.3. Indemnification extends to former officials and members for actions undertaken during their tenure.

➢ 2.1.3.1. The protection shall be limited to acts conducted in the service of KUCSA’s mission and objectives.

➢ 2.1.3.2. Former officials and members must provide documentation proving their official capacity during the disputed action.

Sub-section 2.2: Exemption from Liability

❖ 2.2.1. Members shall not be personally liable for any debts or obligations incurred by KUCSA.

➢ 2.2.1.1. Personal assets of members, officials, and representatives shall not be subject to claims against KUCSA.

➢ 2.2.1.2. This exemption applies only when actions are conducted within the scope of KUCSA's mission and in accordance with this Constitution.

❖ 2.2.2. Liability shall be limited to the assets of KUCSA.

➢ 2.2.2.1. KUCSA’s liability shall be restricted to its financial and material assets as documented in its official records.

➢ 2.2.2.2. Creditors or claimants shall have no recourse to personal property of KUCSA members, provided there is no evidence of fraudulent activity.

❖ 2.2.3. Members shall not bear responsibility for liabilities arising from unauthorized actions.

➢ 2.2.3.1. Unauthorized actions include activities undertaken without prior approval of the Executive Committee or General Assembly.

➢ 2.2.3.2. Members involved in unauthorized actions may face disciplinary measures as outlined in the Code of Conduct.

Sub-section 2.3: Procedures for Claiming Indemnification

❖ 2.3.1. Members or officials seeking indemnification must submit a formal request to the Executive Committee.

➢ 2.3.1.1. Requests must include detailed descriptions of the incident, associated costs, and evidence supporting the claim.

➢ 2.3.1.2. The Executive Committee shall review claims within 30 days of submission.

❖ 2.3.2. Disputes over indemnification eligibility shall be resolved through the Dispute Resolution Mechanism.

➢ 2.3.2.1. Appeals shall be submitted in writing to the General Assembly for final determination.

➢ 2.3.2.2. Decisions made by the General Assembly regarding indemnification shall be binding.

Sub-section 2.4: Insurance Coverage

❖ 2.4.1. KUCSA shall maintain liability insurance to protect its members and assets.

➢ 2.4.1.1. The insurance policy shall cover legal expenses, property damage, and other risks associated with official activities.

➢ 2.4.1.2. The Treasurer shall ensure timely payment of insurance premiums to maintain active coverage.

❖ 2.4.2. Insurance coverage shall not extend to actions outside the scope of KUCSA's official mandate.

➢ 2.4.2.1. Members engaging in personal ventures unrelated to KUCSA shall not be covered under this policy.

➢ 2.4.2.2. Claims arising from intentional violations of laws or regulations shall be excluded.

Sub-section 2.5: Reporting Obligations

❖ 2.5.1. KUCSA shall maintain transparency in its indemnification and liability management.

➢ 2.5.1.1. The Secretary-General shall document all indemnification cases and report annually to the General Assembly.

➢ 2.5.1.2. Financial implications of indemnification shall be included in the Treasurer’s annual financial report.

❖ 2.5.2. Members shall be informed of their indemnification rights and obligations upon joining KUCSA.

➢ 2.5.2.1. Induction materials shall include summaries of indemnification policies and liability exemptions.

➢ 2.5.2.2. Periodic workshops or seminars shall be conducted to educate members about their legal protections.

Section 3: Compliance and Enforcement

Sub-section 3.1: Adherence to Provisions

❖ 3.1.1. All members and officials shall comply with this Constitution.

➢ 3.1.1.1. Members and officials must act in accordance with KUCSA’s principles, objectives, and bylaws as outlined in this Constitution.

➢ 3.1.1.2. Ignorance of the Constitution’s provisions shall not be a defense against allegations of non-compliance.

➢ 3.1.1.3. Members shall undergo periodic training or workshops to understand their roles, responsibilities, and obligations under this Constitution.

❖ 3.1.2. Non-compliance shall attract penalties, including suspension or expulsion.

➢ 3.1.2.1. Penalties for non-compliance shall range from warnings to suspension, expulsion, or disqualification from holding office, depending on the severity of the violation.

➢ 3.1.2.2. Minor offenses, such as procedural lapses, may attract fines or community service as determined by the Disciplinary Committee.

➢ 3.1.2.3. Severe violations, such as misuse of funds, breaches of confidentiality, or gross misconduct, shall be escalated to the Executive Committee for decisive action.

➢ 3.1.2.4. Appeals against penalties must be submitted in writing within 14 days of the decision, and the outcome of the appeal shall be final.

Sub-section 3.2: Enforcement Authority

❖ 3.2.1. The Executive Committee shall have the authority to enforce compliance.

➢ 3.2.1.1. The Executive Committee shall establish a Compliance and Ethics Subcommittee responsible for monitoring adherence to the Constitution.

➢ 3.2.1.2. The Compliance and Ethics Subcommittee shall submit quarterly reports on enforcement actions and recommendations for improvements.

➢ 3.2.1.3. The Executive Committee shall have the authority to summon members for hearings or investigations related to compliance breaches.

❖ 3.2.2. Disciplinary actions shall follow the procedure outlined in the Code of Conduct.

➢ 3.2.2.1. Investigations into alleged violations must be impartial, transparent, and adhere to due process.

■ 3.2.2.1.1. Complaints or reports of violations shall be submitted to the Disciplinary Committee in writing.

■ 3.2.2.1.2. The accused shall be notified of the charges and given an opportunity to respond before any action is taken.

■ 3.2.2.1.3. The Disciplinary Committee shall ensure that both parties are given a fair hearing.

➢ 3.2.2.2. Disciplinary actions may include:

■ 3.2.2.2.1. Verbal or written warnings.

■ 3.2.2.2.2. Temporary suspension from KUCSA activities or roles.

■ 3.2.2.2.3. Permanent expulsion from the Association.

■ 3.2.2.2.4. Legal action in cases involving criminal offenses or breaches of national laws.

❖ 3.2.3. Non-compliance by officials shall result in immediate investigation by the Executive Committee.

➢ 3.2.3.1. Officials found guilty of non-compliance shall face removal from office and may be barred from contesting future positions.

➢ 3.2.3.2. Interim measures, such as temporary suspension, may be implemented to prevent interference with investigations.

Sub-section 3.3: Monitoring and Reporting

❖ 3.3.1. Regular audits shall be conducted to ensure compliance with this Constitution.

➢ 3.3.1.1. The Secretary-General shall maintain records of compliance-related incidents and actions taken.

➢ 3.3.1.2. Annual reviews shall assess the effectiveness of enforcement mechanisms and propose amendments as necessary.

❖ 3.3.2. Members shall report violations promptly to the Compliance and Ethics Subcommittee.

➢ 3.3.2.1. Whistleblowers reporting violations in good faith shall be protected against retaliation.

➢ 3.3.2.2. Anonymous reporting mechanisms shall be provided to encourage reporting of sensitive issues./p>

Sub-section 3.4: Preventative Measures

❖ 3.4.1. KUCSA shall implement preventive strategies to reduce instances of non-compliance.

➢ 3.4.1.1. Educational campaigns shall promote awareness of constitutional provisions among members.

➢ 3.4.1.2. Periodic updates or reminders on constitutional obligations shall be disseminated via official communication channels.

❖ 3.4.2. Training programs shall be mandatory for officials to enhance their understanding of compliance responsibilities.

➢ 3.4.2.1. Newly elected officials must undergo induction training on compliance policies.

➢ 3.4.2.2. Refresher courses shall be organized annually to address emerging compliance challenges.

Sub-section 3.5: Consequences for Failure to Enforce

❖ 3.5.1. The Executive Committee shall be held accountable for lapses in enforcement.

➢ 3.5.1.1. Failure to enforce compliance provisions may result in disciplinary action against negligent officials.

➢ 3.5.1.2. The General Assembly may initiate a vote of no confidence against Executive Committee members who fail in their enforcement duties.

❖ 3.5.2. Non-enforcement of compliance provisions shall be addressed during annual General Assembly reviews.

➢ 3.5.2.1. Members may propose amendments or policies to strengthen enforcement mechanisms during such reviews.

Section 4: Confidentiality

Sub-section 4.1: Obligation to Maintain Confidentiality

❖ 4.1.1. Members shall maintain the confidentiality of sensitive information obtained during their association with KUCSA.

➢ 4.1.1.1. Sensitive information includes, but is not limited to:

■ 4.1.1.1.1. Personal data of members and officials.

■ 4.1.1.1.2. Internal financial records and strategic plans.

■ 4.1.1.1.3. Minutes of Executive Committee and confidential General Assembly meetings.

■ 4.1.1.1.4. Reports from investigations or disciplinary actions.

➢ 4.1.1.2. Members shall sign a confidentiality agreement upon assuming roles involving access to sensitive information.

❖ 4.1.2. Breaches of confidentiality shall be subject to disciplinary action.

➢ 4.1.2.1. Disciplinary actions for breaches may include:

■ 4.1.2.1.1. Written warnings for minor infractions.

■ 4.1.2.1.2. Temporary suspension from KUCSA activities for moderate breaches.

■ 4.1.2.1.3. Expulsion and/or legal action for severe or intentional violations.

➢ 4.1.2.2. Breaches involving financial or strategic information shall be escalated to the Executive Committee for investigation.

Sub-section 4.2: Exceptions

❖ 4.2.1. Confidential information may only be disclosed with prior approval from the Executive Committee or as required by law.

➢ 4.2.1.1. Requests for disclosure must be submitted in writing to the Executive Committee, detailing the purpose and scope of the disclosure.

➢ 4.2.1.2. Disclosures required by law must be accompanied by supporting documentation, such as a court order or subpoena.

➢ 4.2.1.3. In emergencies where prior approval is impractical, disclosures must be reported to the Executive Committee within 48 hours.

❖ 4.2.2. Confidential information may be disclosed to authorized personnel under specific conditions.

➢ 4.2.2.1. Authorized personnel must have a legitimate need to access the information to fulfill their official duties.

➢ 4.2.2.2. Recipients of confidential information must sign a non-disclosure agreement (NDA) before gaining access.

➢ 4.2.2.3. Information disclosed to third parties shall be limited to the minimum necessary for the stated purpose./p>

Sub-section 4.3: Safeguarding Confidential Information

❖ 4.3.1. KUCSA shall implement measures to safeguard sensitive information.

➢ 4.3.1.1. Physical documents containing confidential information shall be stored securely and accessed only by authorized personnel.

➢ 4.3.1.2. Digital information shall be protected using encryption, secure passwords, and access control systems.

➢ 4.3.1.3. Periodic audits shall be conducted to identify vulnerabilities in information security practices.

❖ 4.3.2. Training on confidentiality shall be mandatory for all officials and members with access to sensitive information.

➢ 4.3.2.1. Training shall cover topics such as data protection laws, KUCSA’s confidentiality policies, and handling sensitive information.

➢ 4.3.2.2. Refresher courses shall be conducted annually or as needed.

Sub-section 4.4: Reporting and Addressing Breaches

❖ 4.4.1. Breaches of confidentiality must be reported promptly.

➢ 4.4.1.1. Reports shall be submitted to the Compliance and Ethics Subcommittee or the Executive Committee.

➢ 4.4.1.2. Anonymous reporting channels shall be made available to encourage reporting of breaches.

❖ 4.4.2. Investigations into breaches shall be thorough and impartial.

➢ 4.4.2.1. The Executive Committee shall establish a Confidentiality Oversight Committee to handle investigations into breaches.

➢ 4.4.2.2. Investigations shall include gathering evidence, interviewing involved parties, and determining the severity of the breach.

❖ 4.4.3. Remedies for breaches shall include corrective actions to prevent recurrence.

➢ 4.4.3.1. Corrective actions may involve revising confidentiality policies, improving security measures, or providing additional training.

Sub-section 4.5: Termination of Access

❖ 4.5.1. Access to sensitive information shall cease upon termination of association with KUCSA.

➢ 4.5.1.1. Members and officials must return all documents and materials containing sensitive information within seven days of termination.

➢ 4.5.1.2. Former members and officials remain obligated to maintain confidentiality indefinitely unless formally released from this obligation by the Executive Committee.

Sub-section 4.6: Liability for Unauthorized Disclosure

❖ 4.6.1. Individuals responsible for unauthorized disclosure shall be held accountable.

➢ 4.6.1.1. KUCSA reserves the right to pursue legal action against individuals who intentionally or negligently disclose confidential information.

➢ 4.6.1.2. Individuals may be required to compensate KUCSA for any damages or losses resulting from the disclosure.

❖ 4.6.2. Third parties who misuse disclosed information shall face legal consequences.

➢ 4.6.2.1. KUCSA shall take appropriate legal measures to prevent further misuse of disclosed information.

Section 5: Signatories

Sub-section 5.1: Designated Officials

❖ 5.1.1. The Constitution shall be signed by the Chairperson, Secretary-General, and Treasurer.

➢ 5.1.1.1. Signatures shall be appended during the adoption or amendment of the Constitution.

➢ 5.1.1.2. Each signatory must sign in the presence of at least two witnesses to ensure transparency and authenticity.

❖ 5.1.2. Signatories represent the collective agreement of the Association's leadership.

➢ 5.1.2.1. The act of signing signifies acceptance of the Constitution and commitment to uphold its provisions.

➢ 5.1.2.2. Signatories shall affirm that the Constitution reflects the consensus of the General Assembly and the Executive Committee.

Sub-section 5.2: Role and Responsibilities of Signatories

❖ 5.2.1. Signatories shall ensure that the Constitution is implemented and adhered to by all members.

➢ 5.2.1.1. They shall oversee the dissemination of the Constitution to all stakeholders within KUCSA.

➢ 5.2.1.2. Signatories shall address concerns or ambiguities arising from the interpretation of the Constitution.

❖ 5.2.2. Signatories are responsible for authenticating official amendments or updates.

➢ 5.2.2.1. Amendments to the Constitution shall only be valid when signed by the designated officials.

➢ 5.2.2.2. An authenticated copy of the updated Constitution shall be archived and made accessible to members.

Sub-section 5.3: Replacement of Signatories

❖ 5.3.1. In the event of a change in office, incoming officials shall sign the Constitution within 30 days of assuming their roles.

➢ 5.3.1.1. The outgoing officials shall facilitate the transition and ensure the handover of responsibilities.

➢ 5.3.1.2. New signatories shall affirm their understanding and commitment to the Constitution before appending their signatures.

❖ 5.3.2. Temporary appointments for vacant signatory positions shall be authorized by the Executive Committee.

➢ 5.3.2.1. The interim appointee’s signature shall be valid until the position is filled permanently.

➢ 5.3.2.2. Such appointments must be ratified by the General Assembly within 60 days.

Sub-section 5.4: Procedures for Signing

❖ 5.4.1. Signing ceremonies shall be conducted in an official KUCSA forum.

➢ 5.4.1.1. The event shall be attended by members of the Executive Committee, General Assembly representatives, and other stakeholders.

➢ 5.4.1.2. A record of the signing event, including names, dates, and witnesses, shall be documented and archived.

❖ 5.4.2. Multiple copies of the signed Constitution shall be prepared and distributed.

➢ 5.4.2.1. Official copies shall be stored in the KUCSA Secretariat, and digital versions shall be made accessible to members.

➢ 5.4.2.2. A certified true copy of the Constitution shall be submitted to relevant regulatory bodies, if applicable.

Sub-section 5.5: Revocation and Replacement of Signatures

❖ 5.5.1. A signatory’s endorsement may be revoked under specific circumstances, including:

➢ 5.5.1.1. Gross misconduct, conflict of interest, or failure to uphold the Constitution.

➢ 5.5.1.2. A formal resolution passed by a two-thirds majority of the General Assembly.

❖ 5.5.2. Replacement of signatures after revocation shall follow these guidelines:

➢ 5.5.2.1. The Executive Committee shall nominate a replacement within 14 days of revocation.

➢ 5.5.2.2. The nominee’s signature shall become official upon ratification by the General Assembly.

Sub-section 5.6: Verification of Authenticity

❖ 5.6.1. KUCSA shall establish mechanisms to verify the authenticity of the Constitution's signatures.

➢ 5.6.1.1. Signatures shall be accompanied by official stamps or seals for validation.

➢ 5.6.1.2. Digital copies shall include electronic signatures authenticated through secure systems.

❖ 5.6.2. Disputes over the authenticity of signatures shall be resolved by an independent oversight committee.

➢ 5.6.2.1. The oversight committee shall conduct an investigation and submit its findings to the General Assembly.

➢ 5.6.2.2. Any irregularities identified shall be corrected, and new signatures may be required.

Section 6: Date of Ratification and Effective Date

Sub-section 6.1: Ratification

❖ 6.1.1. This Constitution was ratified on 01/2025.

➢ 6.1.1.1. The date of ratification shall be recorded in official minutes of the General Assembly meeting.

➢ 6.1.1.2. A signed statement of ratification by the Chairperson, Secretary-General, and Treasurer shall be appended to the Constitution.

❖ 6.1.2. Ratification was approved by a two-thirds majority of the General Assembly.

➢ 6.1.2.1. Voting for ratification must adhere to the rules governing quorum and procedures as outlined in this Constitution.

➢ 6.1.2.2. The voting process, whether by show of hands, secret ballot, or electronic means, must be transparent, fair, and documented.

❖ 6.1.3. Ratification shall follow a consultative process involving all stakeholders.

➢ 6.1.3.1. Draft versions of the Constitution shall be circulated to member institutions at least 30 days prior to the General Assembly vote.

➢ 6.1.3.2. Stakeholder consultations, including workshops and forums, shall be conducted to gather input before the final vote.

➢ 6.1.3.3. Proposed amendments arising from consultations shall be reviewed and incorporated by the Constitutional Review Committee.

❖ 6.1.4. Declaration of Ratification.

➢ 6.1.4.1. Upon ratification, the Chairperson shall issue a public declaration to all member institutions, confirming the adoption of the Constitution.

➢ 6.1.4.2. A formal certificate of ratification shall be issued and signed by the Executive Committee.

Sub-section 6.2: Effective Date

❖ 6.2.1. The Constitution shall take effect immediately upon ratification.

➢ 6.2.1.1. The effective date marks the official adoption of the Constitution as the supreme guiding document for KUCSA.

➢ 6.2.1.2. All policies, regulations, and operations of KUCSA must align with the provisions of the Constitution as of the effective date.

❖ 6.2.2. Transitional provisions shall govern the implementation of the Constitution during the first 90 days post-ratification.

➢ 6.2.2.1. Transitional provisions shall address any gaps or conflicts between the previous and current Constitutions.

➢ 6.2.2.2. The Executive Committee shall be tasked with monitoring and guiding the transition process to ensure seamless implementation.

❖ 6.2.3. Notification of the Effective Date.

➢ 6.2.3.1. All member institutions and stakeholders shall be officially notified of the effective date within seven days of ratification.

➢ 6.2.3.2. Notifications shall be disseminated through official KUCSA communication channels, including circulars, emails, and public announcements.

❖ 6.2.4. Legal and Administrative Adjustments.

➢ 6.2.4.1. Any legal agreements or contracts entered into prior to the effective date shall be reviewed to ensure compliance with the new Constitution.

➢ 6.2.4.2. Administrative frameworks, such as committee structures and operational policies, shall be revised to reflect the provisions of the Constitution.

Sub-section 6.3: Review and Confirmation of Ratification Process

❖ 6.3.1. The ratification process shall be reviewed by an independent oversight body to ensure its validity.

➢ 6.3.1.1. The oversight body shall verify that the quorum, voting procedures, and consultations met constitutional requirements.

➢ 6.3.1.2. A report of the review shall be presented to the General Assembly for record-keeping.

❖ 6.3.2. Any challenges or disputes regarding the ratification process must be resolved within 30 days.

➢ 6.3.2.1. The Dispute Resolution Committee shall handle grievances and provide binding recommendations.

➢ 6.3.2.2. Resolutions may include re-voting or procedural adjustments to address identified concerns.

Sub-section 6.4: Amendments to the Ratification and Effective Date Provisions

❖ 6.4.1. Provisions governing ratification and the effective date may only be amended by a two-thirds majority vote of the General Assembly.

➢ 6.4.1.1. Proposals for amendments must be submitted in writing to the Constitutional Review Committee.

➢ 6.4.1.2. A detailed justification for the proposed changes must accompany the submission.

❖ 6.4.2. Amendments must undergo stakeholder consultation before adoption.

➢ 6.4.2.1. Member institutions shall have a 30-day period to review and provide feedback on proposed changes.

➢ 6.4.2.2. A special session of the General Assembly shall be convened to deliberate on the amendments.

© © 2024 Kenya Universities and Colleges Students Association (KUCSA). All rights reserved!.
